docBody.head: Better Babies

p.q: Forty years ago an attractive, red-haired trained nurse working in the slums of New York was horrified to hear of the death of a young mother in a nearby tenement.

She knew the mother was passionately fond of her children, so much that she wanted no more offspring to divide her devotion, energies and the meager but adequate income of her husband. Her one wish was that her children, despite their slum environment would never become unwanted burdens of society. With her death that is exactly what they did become.
But what horrified the nurse was that she also knew the mother had died of an illegal operation performed to prevent the birth of a fourth child.

The mother is nameless, one of thousands who have died of interrupted pregnancies, but the nurse's name was Margaret Sanger, and it was this experience which inspired her to crusade for birth control, a term she herself originated.

docBody.p: "What I want is wanted children," said Mrs. Sanger yesterday at the Reef.
"You can't set a size for all families--the number of children depends on the particular situation of the parents--but a child should be wanted before it is born.
"It should not have to be unwatned, abused, cruelly treated, or brought into an environment of misery and even death by parents who have no right to have children."
"Recently, while I was in India, I asked mothers about the health of their pathetic babies. Often the answer was 'Baby hungry in my belly too long.'
"The child was starving before it was born.
"Do you realize 66 per cent of India's population never has one full meal a day? Ninety per cent has never known meat. The only milk they've tasted is their mother's.
"Asia has more than one-half the population of the globe crowded in one-sixth of its land area, and 50,000 babies are added to it EVERY day.
"The world population is far outdistancing the food supply, especially proteins. According to the Department of Agriculture, it takes 100 good grazing acres to give nine people meat once a day.
"In 1936 I traveled in India a year, setting up 65 birth control centers. War destroyed many of them, but the seeds were sown.
"I just received a letter this week saying that the Indian government has agreed to allocate $8 million to be used solely for family planning work.

"In 1954 I was invited to Japan by Hidejo Kawasaka, the minister of health, who is doing everything in his power to help the people of his country control the size of their families. The midwives are now instructed to teach birth control.

"I predict that it won't take many generations for India and Japan to lead the world in eugenic populations because the governments are now directing their efforts in slum areas to controlling the increase of the transmissibly diseased and dysgenic portions of the population.

"In America, which has as many new babies as India, we haven't touched the lower strata of society for whom the movement was started. The women are so family-bound that they are unable to visit one of the 600 clinics of the Planned Parenthood League throughout America.
"The public health officials are also the sinners; they make no effort and have no policy for teaching birth control.
"Also the movement lacks funds for research. We are using today the same methods that I brought back from Germany and Hollandin 1915.

"Fortunately it is a method which requires a doctor's advice in adjustment, so the medical profession has been brought into the movement. But it is a method which is outdated compared to the advances made in other fields of science.

"The oral contraceptive, or pill, called Progesterone, which is being developed in the research laboratory of Dr. Pincus, of Worcester, has proved 100 per cent satisfactory with animals as well as with the controlled number of women tested.
"The woman is immunized against conception for periods which last four months. But the pill does not sterilize, and she can conceive when the four month's immunization wears off.

"I feel like the ideal solution is an injection which can be administered every six months. Science has developed vaccinations against cholera, diphtheria, polio and countless other threats to the health of mankind. It is not impossible that the day will come when family planning will be as simple and universal.
"On that day you will see the birth of a happier, healthier world population."
